issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Ride with an attribute named 'shortCode: char' (problem_statement.md) but the solution implementation uses a field named 'abbreviation' and a getter getAbbreviation() (solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/Ride.java). This name mismatch between the specification and the reference implementation can confuse students about the expected attribute/getter name (e.g., getShortCode() vs getAbbreviation()) and may cause test/name-based checks to fail or students to implement a differently named getter than the solution expects.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute name consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the UML/problem statement to name the attribute 'abbreviation: char' (and document the getter getAbbreviation()), or (B) rename the field and getter in the solution to 'shortCode' / getShortCode() so they match the UML. Ensure the constructor parameter order and public getter names are updated accordingly in all artifacts.

issues.description: The UML/problem statement names the Ride attribute as 'shortCode' (Ride -shortCode: char) but the solution (and template placeholders) use the identifier 'abbreviation' for the same attribute, its constructor parameter, and its getter (getAbbreviation()). This creates a naming mismatch between the problem description and the provided implementation: students reading the UML expect 'shortCode' but must work with 'abbreviation' in the code, increasing cognitive load and risking mismatches with test expectations that derive names from the UML.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the identifier across artifacts. Rename the Ride attribute, its constructor parameter, and getter from 'abbreviation' to 'shortCode' (and getter to getShortCode()) in the template and solution so they match the UML/problem statement. Alternatively, update the UML/problem statement to use 'abbreviation' if that name is preferred — but keep the same identifier in all artifacts to avoid student confusion.
